objtitle.title: *The Canterbury Pilgrims: Sketch for the Engraving*

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.dealer: Stephen Somerville of Somerville and Simpson
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 161 (£1.2s. to the dealer C. J. Toovey); Henry Cunliffe; offered Sotheby's, 11 May 1895, lot 100 (bought-in at £2.19s. by Mrs. Cunliffe); Henry Cunliffe's great-nephew Rolf, 2nd Lord Cunliffe; his son, Merlin Cunliffe, probably by inheritance in 1963; sold from Merlin Cunliffe's collection, Christie's, 15 Nov. 1983, lot 132 (£12,960 to the dealer Stephen Somerville of Somerville and Simpson on behalf of the British Museum).

desc.objtitle:
The Canterbury Pilgrims: Sketch for the Engraving,
Object 1 (Butlin 654)

objnote.p: The verso is inscribed by Frederick Tatham, "The Original reduced Drawing made to reduce the Picture of the Canterbury Pilgrims to the size of the Plate Blake afterwards engraved". This statement is an accurate description of the role played by this drawing as the transition between Blake's tempera painting of 1808, *Sir Jeffery Chaucer and the Nine and Twenty Pilgrims on Their Journey to Canterbury* (Butlin 653) and the engraving, *Chaucers Canterbury Pilgrims*, dated 1810 in the imprint. The relationship between this drawing and some circular forms sketched in pencil on its verso is uncertain. If related at all, they may be Blake's way of blocking out areas to be developed into groups of pilgrims on the recto. The verso is not reproduced here.
